It will warn you that the collection is not signed, but it is fine, click “Add Unsigned Collection”.
Now you can add any of the AudioKit Swift Packages you need and read about what they do, right from within Xcode.

As described by Will Pirkle in his excellent book “Designing Audio Effect Plug-Ins in C++”, chorus and flanger are modulated-delay effects. A short delay line is used (up to 10 ms for flanger, or 24 ms for chorus), and the delay time is modulated using a low-frequency oscillator (LFO). Feedback is always used for flanging, typically not for chorus. There is also a wet/dry mix setting, which will normally be 50/50 for flanging. Setting the mix to 100% wet (for either effect) produces vibrato.
The code here is all original; none of Pirkle’s code has been used.
These are both stereo effects (stereo-in, stereo-out). The modulator LFO signals used for the left and right channels are the same frequency, but differ in phase by 90 degrees.
These effects all take up to four parameters as follows:
Frequency of the modulating LFO, Hz. Acceptable range 0.1 to 10.0 Hz. For chorus and flanger, you will usually use rates less than 2 Hz. For vibrato, 5 Hz sounds good.
Depth of modulation, expressed as a fraction 0.0 - 1.0. The higher the number, the more pronounced the effect.

Another fractional scale factor which is the amount of delayed signal which is “fed back” into the input of the delay block. For flanger (which requires at least some feedback), the acceptable range is -0.95 - +0.95; negative values mean the feedback signal is inverted. For chorus (where feedback is usually not used), the acceptable range is 0.0 - 0.25. In both cases, numbers further from zero yield more pronounced effect.
The effects’ output is a mix of the input (“dry”) signal and the delayed (“wet”) signal. The
value is the scale factor (always a fraction 0.0 - 1.0) for the wet signal. The scale factor for the dry signal is computed internally as 1.0 -
, so they always sum to unity. The higher the
value, the more pronounced the effect.
. These are all achieved by mixing an input signal with a delayed version of itself, and modulating the delay-time with a low-frequency oscillator (LFO).

The LFO’s output (typically a sinusoid or triangle wave) sets the instantaneous delay-time (i.e., the position of the output tap along the  delay-line’s length), which then varies cyclically between limits
The balance between the “dry” (input) signal and the “wet” (delayed) signal is usually set based on a user-selected fraction

For a chorus effect, the delay time varies about
which is fixed at the midpoint of the delay-line, whose total length is typically 20-40 ms. A user-selected

parameter to 1.0 (maximum) results in actual delay values of 14 ± 10 ms, i.e.

, from a minimum of zero to a maximum of about 7-10 ms. Typical settings include a 50/50 wet/dry mix, and at least some feedback.

parameter is a signed fraction in the range -1.0 to + 1.0, where negative values indicate that the signal is inverted before begin fed back. This is important because when the delay time gets very close to zero, the low-frequency parts of the wet and dry signals overlap almost perfectly, so positive feedback can result in a sudden increase in volume. Using negative feedback instead yields a momentary reduction in volume, which is less noticeable.
may vary from -0.95 to +0.95. LFO is a triangle wave, 0.1 - 10 Hz.
With a modulated-delay effect in either chorus (
fixed at midpoint of delay-line) or flanger (
fixed at near-zero) configuration, setting the

to 100% will yield a vibrato effect. This is due to the effect of the LFO modulating the delay time. When the delay-time is decreasing, the short fragment of sound in the delay-line is effectively resampled at a rate faster than its original sample rate, so the pitch rises. When the delay-time is increasing, the sound is resampled at a rate slower than its original sampling rate, so the pitch drops.
are actually stereo effects. The DSP structure shown in the above diagram is duplicated for each of the Left and Right channels. The two LFOs run in lock-step at the same frequency (set by the
), but offset in phase by 90 degrees. This technique, called
, is quite common in stereo modulation effects.
Modulated-delay effects are described in detail in Chapter 10 of

is a new, polyphonic sample-playback engine built from scratch in C++.  It is 64-voice polyphonic and features a per-voice, stereo low-pass filter with resonance and ADSR envelopes for both amplitude and filter cutoff. Samples must be loaded into memory and remain resident there; it does not do streaming.  It reads standard audio files via
, as well as a more efficient
Audio Unit, an exceptionally powerful polyphonic, multi-timbral sampler instrument which is built-in to both macOS and iOS. Unfortunately,
is far from perfect and not properly documented. This
is an attempt to provide an open-source alternative.
is nowhere near as powerful as
wrapper class, you should continue to use it.
provides three distinct mechanisms for loading samples:
allows use of sample data already in memory, e.g. data generated programmatically or read using custom file-reading code.
loads entire sets of samples by interpreting a simplistic subset of the “SFZ” soundfont file format.

take a “descriptor” argument (see next section below), whose many member variables define details like the sample’s natural MIDI note-number and pitch (frequency), plus details about loop start and end points, if used. For
allows all this “metadata” to be encoded in a SFZ file, using a simple plain-text format which is easy to understand and edit manually.
The mapping of MIDI (note number, velocity) pairs to samples is done using some internal lookup tables, which can be populated in one of two ways:
When your metadata includes min/max note-number and velocity values for all samples, call
to build a full key/velocity map.
If you only have note-numbers for each sample, call
to map each MIDI note-number (at any velocity) to the
Before loading a new group of samples, you must call
. Otherwise, the new samples will be loaded
to the already-loaded ones. This wastes memory and worse, newly-loaded samples will usually not sound at all, because the sampler simply plays the first matching sample it finds.
to load individual samples, you will need to create instances of one of three Swift structure types as follows.
The structures are defined as C structs in
folder in the main AudioKit repo). This file is simple enough to reproduce here:
By the miracle of Swift/Objective-C bridging (see
), each of these three structures is accessible from Swift as a similarly-named class, which you can create by simply providing values for all the properties, as you’ll see in the examples below.

is the sampling rate at which the sample data were acquired. If the sampler needs to play back the sample at a different rate, it will need to scale its playback rate based on the ratio of the two rates.

will be 1 if the sample is monophonic, or 2 if stereo. Note the sampler can play back mono samples as stereo; it simply plays the same data to both output channels. (In the reverse case, only the Left channel data will sound.)
only for stereo samples represented in memory as Left1, Right1, Left2, Right2, etc. Set
for mono samples, or non-interleaved stereo samples where all the Left samples come first, followed by all the Right samples.
is a pointer to the raw sample data; it has the slightly-scary Swift type

This document describes the process of preparing a set of demonstration samples, starting with the sample files included with
You can download the finished product from
The demo samples were recorded and prepared by Matthew Fecher from a Yamaha TX81z hardware FM synthesizer module, using commercial sampling software called
on the Mac, you can use its excellent
If you’re planning to work with existing samples, or capture the output from a sample-based instrument,
give careful consideration to copyright issues
Be very careful with SoundFont files you find on the Internet.

Many are marked “public domain”, but actually consist of unlicensed, illegally copied content. While such things are fine for your own personal use, distributing them publicly with your name attached (e.g. in an iOS app on the App Store) can land you in serious legal trouble.
Turning a set of rough digital recordings into cleanly-playing, looping samples is a complex process in itself, which is beyond the scope of this document. For a quick introduction, see
. For in-depth exploration, look into YouTube videos by
software. On the Mac, you must first install the Wavpack command-line tools. Then you can use the following Python 2 script to compress a whole folder-full of
Uncomment the last line if you’re sure you want to delete WAV files after converting them.

file format, which is too bad because that’s what

command-line utility built into macOS to convert
Mapping of MIDI (note-number, velocity) pairs to sample files requires additional data, for which
uses a simple subset of the
. SFZ is essentially a text-based, open-standard alternative to the proprietary
In addition to key-mapping, SFZ files can also contain other important metadata such as loop-start and -end points for each sample file.
The full SFZ standard is very rich, but at the time of writing,
’s SFZ import capability is limited to key mapping and loop metadata only.

content.text: Other methods to create SFZ files

inlineContent.text: Since SFZ files are simply plain-text files, you can use an ordinary text editor to create them.
At the other end of the scale, a company called Chicken Systems sells a very powerful tool called

, which can convert both sample and metadata to and from a huge list of professional formats, including ESX24 (Apple), SoundFont (SF2 and SFZ), Kontakt 5 (Native Instruments), and many more. The full version costs $149 (USD), but if you’re only interested in converting to SFZ, you can buy the “Special Edition” for just $79.
produces AIFF-C audio files and an EXS24 metadata file, in a newer format than vonRed’s
script can handle. However, all the necessary details are actually encoded right in the
sample files. The following Python script uses a simplistic parsing technique to pull the necessary numbers out of a set of

code: sfz.write('<group>lokey=%d hikey=%d pitch_keycenter=%d pitch_keytrack=100\n' % (noteNumber-2, noteNumber+3, noteNumber))

It won’t work with all AIFF files

. The following is a preliminary version of a new Python 2.7 script which does a better job of parsing an individual AIFF file:

code: channels, frames, bitsPerSample, exp, mant = struct.unpack('>hIhhQ', data)
# simplified conversion of 80-bit SANE float, using 1st 32 bits of mantissa
baseNote, detune, lowNote, highNote, lowVel, highVel, gain = struct.unpack('>bbbbbbh', chk.read(8))

content.text: Simple Example of a simple SFZ file

inlineContent.text: If your sampling needs are not very complex, as in, you simply just need to load your
with a variety samples, here is an example of a working SFZ File:
This SFZ file is an example of a piano sampler with samples matched note for note in most octaves. Let’s go over from top to bottom:
This is a necessary SFZ keyword to denote that this is indeed a SFZ file.
The path in which the samples you are describing in the SFZ file reside. In this example SFZ file, we have a folder named
that is in the same directory as the SFZ file. You may name your folder any name, as long as it is described correctly in the SFZ file.

You will need to ensure that your folder of samples and the path is described correctly. If your SFZ file resides in a different directory, please be sure find the correct path for the folder of samples so that the SFZ can correctly find them
. Here we are preparing the MIDI note 33 to be assigned to a sample.
Here we are assigning a specific sample you have collected to the above group/key.
Our sampler will assign key 33 to the sample
In this example file, we are just continuing to assign 1 to 1 keys to samples.
Lets look at the last 2 lines:
allows us to use one sample to map to multiple keys or MIDI notes.
tells us where to center the key or MIDI note for the sample. In these two lines, we are assigning the sample

80. The sampler will pitch shift the sample in order to accommodate the higher/lower notes. Be aware that small amounts of pitch shifting will be hard to discern, but anything past a Perfect 5th (7 semitones) will start to exhibit pitch shifting artifacts. Check out more information on

Whatever methods you use to create samples and metadata files, it’s important to test, test, test, to make sure things are working the way you want.
The subject of preparing sample sets is deep and complex, and this article has barely scratched the surface. We hope to provide additional online resources as time goes on, especially as
’s implementation expands and changes. Interested users, especially those with practical experience to share, are encouraged to get in touch with the AudioKit team to help with this process.
